>2nd, I have noticed that if one sends powerfull enough attacks at a
>door, the door will open automatically WITHOUT using any keys.  Can
>someone at FS Games explains how this little bug works?

Sure -- when we put doors into the game, we wanted to make sure there was 
always *some* way around them -- that is, if we really wanted to block an 
area, we'd use a "real" blocker of some kind.

The thought was that, say, there was a key hidden in the southwest corner 
of a map. If, for some reason, the player just *couldn't* get it, for some 
reason, we didn't want them to give up.  So we made doors work basically 
like "really high hitpoint" creatures.  Generally (unless you're using 
boosted characters) it takes more work to destroy a door by force than just 
by finding the darn key.  But if you really want to just blow the darn 
thing up, you can.

>3rd, Can someone at FS Games tell me the specific limitations on how
>much strength, dex, con, intelligence, and experience are the maximum?
>  I want to make sure I do NOT design a level too close to those
>extremes.

Generally, each character stat uses a signed 16-big integer.  That means 
the larger number in those areas is going to be about 32,767.

However, remember that the stats interact with each other.  For example 
(and this isn't a real formula we use), let's say that "bonus points" 
assigned to a character are equal to:
         STR / 4         +               INT / 2         +       DEX

.. or something like that.  That means when your values get near the top 
(especially if the formulas contain "multiplies" in them), you'll suddenly 
wrap from having 32,725 or so "Bonus points" to having some low, or even 
negative, number. (Sometimes all <0 numbers are considered 0; sometimes 
they're treated as normal negative numbers).

>   I have also noticed that when a level 255 archmage summons
>a fire elemental, the elemental's health and magic power are listed
>as  negative numbers.  Can someone as FS Games explain this one?

Basically, the above answer: the elemental's values are set based on its 
owners; some part of the formula which determines how powerful it is ends 
up "looping" over the maximum value.

--Tom
